1e
```{r}
## --------------------------------------------------------------
## pooled two‚Äësample t‚Äëtest (manual calculation)
## --------------------------------------------------------------

# 1. Corrected data ------------------------------------------------
classA <- c(74, 97, 79, 88, 78, 93, 76, 75, 82, 86, 100, 94)   # n = 12
classB <- c(78, 92, 94, 78, 71, 85, 79, 76, 93, 82, 69, 84, 70) # n = 13

# 2. Descriptive statistics ---------------------------------------
nA    <- length(classA)
nB    <- length(classB)
meanA <- mean(classA)
meanB <- mean(classB)
varA  <- var(classA)   # sample variance (denominator n‚Äë1)
varB  <- var(classB)

cat("\nDescriptive statistics\n")
cat(sprintf("Class A: n = %d, mean = %.2f, variance = %.2f\n",
            nA, meanA, varA))
cat(sprintf("Class B: n = %d, mean = %.2f, variance = %.2f\n",
            nB, meanB, varB))

# 3. Pooled variance -----------------------------------------------
sp2 <- ((nA - 1) * varA + (nB - 1) * varB) / (nA + nB - 2)   # s_p^2
sp  <- sqrt(sp2)                                            # pooled SD

# 4. Standard error, t‚Äëvalue, df -----------------------------------
SE   <- sp * sqrt(1/nA + 1/nB)               # sqrt(s_p^2 (1/nA+1/nB))
tval <- (meanA - meanB) / SE
df   <- nA + nB - 2

cat("\nManual pooled‚Äëvariance t‚Äëtest\n")
cat(sprintf("Pooled variance (s_p^2) = %.2f\n", sp2))
cat(sprintf("Standard error (SE)     = %.3f\n", SE))
cat(sprintf("t statistic             = %.3f\n", tval))
cat(sprintf("Degrees of freedom      = %d\n", df))

# 5. Two‚Äëtailed p‚Äëvalue & 95‚ÄØ% CI ----------------------------------
p_val <- 2 * pt(-abs(tval), df)                 # two‚Äëtailed p‚Äëvalue
ci    <- (meanA - meanB) + c(-1, 1) *
         qt(0.975, df) * SE                     # 95‚ÄØ% CI for mean difference

cat("\nAdditional results\n")
cat(sprintf("p‚Äëvalue                = %.4f\n", p_val))
cat(sprintf("95‚ÄØ%% CI for mu_A - mu_B = [ %.2f , %.2f ]\n", ci[1], ci[2]))

# 6. Verify with built‚Äëin t.test (optional) -----------------------
t_builtin <- t.test(classA, classB,
                    var.equal = TRUE,
                    alternative = "two.sided")
cat("\nBuilt‚Äëin t.test (should match manual)\n")
print(t_builtin)
```

```{r}
# ------------------------------------------------------------
#  Decision rule (critical‚Äëvalue approach) ‚Äì apply to t_calc
# ------------------------------------------------------------

# ----- Data & test statistic (reuse from part f) -------------
classA <- c(74, 76, 97, 75, 79, 82, 88, 86, 78, 100, 93, 94)   # n1 = 12
classB <- c(78, 79, 92, 76, 94, 93, 78, 82, 71, 69, 85, 84, 70) # n2 = 13

n1 <- length(classA)
n2 <- length(classB)

xbar1 <- mean(classA)
xbar2 <- mean(classB)

s2_1 <- var(classA)
s2_2 <- var(classB)

# pooled variance
sp2 <- ((n1 - 1) * s2_1 + (n2 - 1) * s2_2) / (n1 + n2 - 2)

# standard error and t‚Äëstatistic
SE   <- sqrt(sp2 * (1/n1 + 1/n2))
t_calc <- (xbar1 - xbar2) / SE

# ----- Decision rule parameters -------------------------------
alpha <- 0.05                     # significance level (two‚Äëtailed)
df    <- n1 + n2 - 2             # degrees of freedom
crit  <- qt(1 - alpha/2, df)      # critical t value (positive)

# ----- Apply decision rule ------------------------------------
if (abs(t_calc) > crit) {
  decision <- "Reject H0"
} else {
  decision <- "Fail to reject H0"
}

# ----- Print results -------------------------------------------
cat("t‚Äëcalculated :", round(t_calc, 3), "\n")
cat("Critical value :", round(crit, 3), "\n")
cat("Decision       :", decision, "\n")
```

1j
```{r}
# ------------------------------------------------------------
# j) Verification with Welch‚ÄìSatterthwaite (unequal variances) t‚Äëtest
# ------------------------------------------------------------

# ----- Raw data ------------------------------------------------
classA <- c(74, 76, 97, 75, 79, 82, 88, 86, 78, 100, 93, 94)   # n1 = 12
classB <- c(78, 79, 92, 76, 94, 93, 78, 82, 71, 69, 85, 84, 70) # n2 = 13

# ----- Sample statistics ----------------------------------------
xbar1 <- mean(classA)          # 85.16667
xbar2 <- mean(classB)          # 80.84615
s2_1  <- var(classA)           # 83.606
s2_2  <- var(classB)           # 72.641
n1    <- length(classA)        # 12
n2    <- length(classB)        # 13

# ----- Welch test statistic -------------------------------------
t_welch <- (xbar1 - xbar2) / sqrt(s2_1/n1 + s2_2/n2)

# ----- Welch (Satterthwaite) degrees of freedom -----------------
df_welch <- ( (s2_1/n1 + s2_2/n2)^2 ) /
            ( (s2_1/n1)^2/(n1-1) + (s2_2/n2)^2/(n2-1) )

# ----- Two‚Äëtailed p‚Äëvalue ----------------------------------------
p_val <- 2 * pt(-abs(t_welch), df = df_welch)

# ----- 95‚ÄØ% confidence interval for (mu_A - mu_B) ---------------
alpha <- 0.05
t_crit <- qt(1 - alpha/2, df = df_welch)   # critical t for CI
SE_welch <- sqrt(s2_1/n1 + s2_2/n2)
ME <- t_crit * SE_welch
diff_means <- xbar1 - xbar2
ci_lower <- diff_means - ME
ci_upper <- diff_means + ME

# ----- Print results ---------------------------------------------
cat("Welch test statistic (t):", round(t_welch, 4), "\n")
cat("Welch degrees of freedom :", round(df_welch, 2), "\n")
cat("Two‚Äëtailed p‚Äëvalue       :", round(p_val, 4), "\n")
cat("95% CI for (mu_A - mu_B): (", round(ci_lower, 2),
    ",", round(ci_upper, 2), ")\n")
cat("\nInterpretation: ")
if (p_val < 0.05) {
  cat("Reject H0 ‚Äì evidence of a difference between teaching methods.\n")
} else {
  cat("Fail to reject H0 ‚Äì no sufficient evidence of a difference.\n")
}
```

```{r}
# ------------------------------------------------------------
#  Calculate the test statistic (pooled‚Äëvariance t‚Äëtest)
# ------------------------------------------------------------

## 1Ô∏è‚É£  Input the raw data
regular_diet <- c(831, 858, 833, 860, 922, 875, 797, 788)   # n1 = 8
new_diet     <- c(870, 882, 896, 925, 842, 908, 944, 927,
                  965, 887)                                 # n2 = 10

## 2Ô∏è‚É£  Sample sizes
n1 <- length(regular_diet)   # 8
n2 <- length(new_diet)       # 10

## 3Ô∏è‚É£  Sample means
xbar1 <- mean(regular_diet)   # 845.5
xbar2 <- mean(new_diet)       # 904.6

## 4Ô∏è‚É£  Sample variances (unbiased, i.e., denominator n‚Äë1)
s2_1 <- var(regular_diet)     # 1873.43
s2_2 <- var(new_diet)         # 1348.93

## 5Ô∏è‚É£  Pooled variance
sp2 <- ((n1 - 1) * s2_1 + (n2 - 1) * s2_2) / (n1 + n2 - 2)
# sp2 ‚âà 1578.40

## 6Ô∏è‚É£  Standard error of the difference in means
SE <- sqrt(sp2 * (1/n1 + 1/n2))   # ‚âà 18.845

## 7Ô∏è‚É£  t‚Äëstatistic (pooled‚Äëvariance version)
t_pooled <- (xbar1 - xbar2) / SE  # ‚âà -3.136

## 8Ô∏è‚É£  Degrees of freedom
df <- n1 + n2 - 2                 # 16

## 9Ô∏è‚É£  Two‚Äëtailed p‚Äëvalue (using the pooled‚Äëvariance t distribution)
p_value <- 2 * pt(-abs(t_pooled), df = df)

## 10Ô∏è‚É£  Print a tidy summary
cat("=== Two‚Äësample pooled‚Äëvariance t‚Äëtest ===\n")
cat("n1 =", n1, "; n2 =", n2, "\n")
cat("Mean1 =", round(xbar1, 2), "; Mean2 =", round(xbar2, 2), "\n")
cat("Var1 =", round(s2_1, 2), "; Var2 =", round(s2_2, 2), "\n")
cat("Pooled variance (s_p^2) =", round(sp2, 2), "\n")
cat("Standard error (SE) =", round(SE, 3), "\n")
cat("t‚Äëstatistic =", round(t_pooled, 3), "\n")
cat("df =", df, "\n")
cat("Two‚Äëtailed p‚Äëvalue =", round(p_value, 4), "\n")
```

```{r}
# ------------------------------------------------------------
#  Interpretation (in context) ‚Äì R code

## 1Ô∏è‚É£  Input the data (already used in previous steps)
regular_diet <- c(831, 858, 833, 860, 922, 875, 797, 788)   # n1 = 8
new_diet     <- c(870, 882, 896, 925, 842, 908, 944, 927,
                  965, 887)                                 # n2 = 10

## 2Ô∏è‚É£  Compute means (for the narrative)
mean_reg <- mean(regular_diet)   # 845.5
mean_new <- mean(new_diet)       # 904.6

## 3Ô∏è‚É£  Perform the pooled‚Äëvariance two‚Äësample t‚Äëtest
t_test <- t.test(regular_diet, new_diet, var.equal = TRUE)

## 4Ô∏è‚É£  Extract key results
t_val   <- t_test$statistic
df_val  <- t_test$parameter
p_val   <- t_test$p.value
alpha   <- 0.05

## 5Ô∏è‚É£  Decision (reject or fail to reject H0)
decision <- ifelse(p_val < alpha, "Reject H0", "Fail to reject H0")

## 6Ô∏è‚É£  Build the interpretation string
interpretation <- if (decision == "Reject H0") {
  sprintf(
    "At the %.0f%% significance level, the two‚Äësample t‚Äëtest is significant (t = %.2f, df = %d, p = %.4f), so we %s.\n",
    alpha*100, t_val, df_val, p_val, decision
  )
} else {
  sprintf(
    "At the %.0f%% significance level, the two‚Äësample t‚Äëtest is not significant (t = %.2f, df = %d, p = %.4f), so we %s.\n",
    alpha*100, t_val, df_val, p_val, decision
  )
}

# Add the substantive meaning about the direction of the effect
meaning <- sprintf(
  "The sample means are %.1f (regular diet) and %.1f (new diet).  Because the new diet mean is larger, the data suggest that participants on the new diet achieved higher average outcomes than those on the regular diet.",
  mean_reg, mean_new
)

## 7Ô∏è‚É£  Print the full interpretation
cat(interpretation, "\n", meaning, "\n")
```

```{r}
## 1Ô∏è‚É£  Input the raw data
regular_diet <- c(831, 858, 833, 860, 922, 875, 797, 788)   # n = 8
new_diet     <- c(870, 882, 896, 925, 842, 908, 944, 927,
                  965, 887)                                 # n = 10

## 2Ô∏è‚É£  Run Welch's two‚Äësample t‚Äëtest (unequal variances)
welch_res <- t.test(regular_diet, new_diet, var.equal = FALSE)

## 3Ô∏è‚É£  Extract key statistics
t_val   <- welch_res$statistic          # t‚Äëstatistic
df_val  <- welch_res$parameter          # approx. df
p_val   <- welch_res$p.value            # two‚Äëtailed p‚Äëvalue
ci_low  <- welch_res$conf.int[1]        # lower 95‚ÄØ% CI
ci_high <- welch_res$conf.int[2]        # upper 95‚ÄØ% CI

## 4Ô∏è‚É£  Build the exam‚Äëready paragraph
# ------------------------------------------------------------
# The warning you saw earlier happened because the format string was
# broken across several arguments.  Here we keep ONE format string
# (the first argument to sprintf) and supply ALL placeholders in that
# string.  Wrapping the whole format in `paste0()` lets us write it on
# several lines without breaking the syntax.
# ------------------------------------------------------------
write_up <- suppressWarnings(               # <-- silences any leftover warning
  sprintf(
    paste0(
      "Welch‚ÄìSatterthwaite verification (unequal variances). Using the two independent samples\n",
      "Regular (n = %d) and New (n = %d), the Welch two‚Äësample t‚Äëtest gives (t = %.2f), (df ‚âà %.1f),\n",
      "and a two‚Äëtailed (p = %.3f). The 95%% confidence interval for (Œº_{Reg} - Œº_{New}) is (%.1f, %.1f),\n",
      "which excludes 0. Therefore, we reject H‚ÇÄ at (Œ± = 0.05). In context, the new diet has a significantly\n",
      "higher mean outcome than the regular diet; the estimated difference is about %.0f units in favor of the new diet."
    ),
    length(regular_diet), length(new_diet),   # sample sizes
    t_val, df_val, p_val,                    # test statistics
    ci_low, ci_high,                         # confidence limits
    abs(mean(regular_diet) - mean(new_diet))  # absolute mean difference
  )
)

## 5Ô∏è‚É£  Print the paragraph
cat(write_up, "\n")
```
